Award.AwardTitle: Shift In Shedding Frequency In Multiphase Flow Past A Cylinder

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Vortices are shed from tubes in heat exchangers and in countless other commonly encountered flows of practical importance. The shed vortices can excite vibration in the equipment, which in turn can lead to inefficient operation or damage, which is a known phenomenon and usually accounted for in the design. However, if the liquid flow past an object like a tube contains gas or vapor bubbles, the shedding frequency can shift and hence excite potentially unexpected frequencies. The flows with a shift in the shedding frequency remain only partially understood. The goal of this research is to better understand the physical mechanisms of multiphase flows encountering a bluff body (i.e. an object that is not streamlined). This research will provide recorded visualizations for K-12 students explaining the bubbly-fluid physical phenomena. This interaction will introduce a diverse student population to the relevant physics of these flows with the goal of increasing interest in the STEM field.

To gain a deeper understanding of vortex shedding in multiphase flows, a carefully planned fundamental study is undertaken on the physical mechanisms relevant to a bubbly flow past a cylinder in a nominally two-dimensional flow. The research will utilize state-of-art experimental techniques, theory, and numerical modelling to gain a thorough understanding of the flow over a wide range of parameters. The numerical simulations will be carried out using high-order accurate flow solvers with adaptive meshes and large eddy simulation models. The bubble size has a predictable effect on the probability and rate of bubble entrainment to boundary layers and vortex cores in a flow past a cylinder. Small bubbles act as passive tracers, whereas for large bubbles buoyancy dominates. However, for intermediate size bubbles there is a notable nonlinear dependence on probability of bubble capture in the vortices on bubble size. For conditions where bubbles accumulate in the vortices at disproportionate rate and increasing local void fraction, there is an enhanced shift in shedding frequency. Hence, the questions to be studied include: what are the dominant mechanisms controlling gas accumulation in the vortex cores, does the modification of the underlying flow by the dispersed phase affect vortex shedding by mechanisms other than modification of average density in wake, and does the vortex shedding frequency bifurcate as suggested by previous investigatorsâ€™ data?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of California-Berkeley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
As fluid moves past a bluff body such as a mooring line, pipe or support column, alternating flow patterns are introduced into the wake and these induce vibration in the structure. In single phase flow (e.g., just water) this vortex induced vibration mechanism is fairly well understood, and based on the wake characteristics can be broadly classified as subcritical flow (generally at lower speeds) or supercritical flow (generally at higher speeds). However, when gas bubbles are introduced into the water flow the wake behavior changes in ways that are less understood.  Previous studies have shown that the frequency of vortices shed in the wake can be altered due to the presence of the bubbles in water, and that this change is dependent on the speed of the flow, the geometry of the bluff body (e.g., diameter of the cylinder), bubble size, and gas volume fraction. Our study focused on the influence of these parameters on modification of the flow past the cylinder, and on the cylinder’s vibration frequency and amplitude. The focus was on better understanding the physical mechanisms that cause these changes.

The key findings are detailed in (published and soon to be published) journal papers and shared with the community in presentations where the mechanisms thought to cause the changes are discussed in depth. For brevity we only note the most striking findings in this outcomes report. For gas volume fractions orders of magnitude smaller than expected to significantly influence the flow we found that under some of the experimental conditions the vortex induced vibrations were suppressed and the flow regime could be shifted from subcritical to supercritical. Specifically, in the subcritical regime, we found that introducing mere 0.01% gas by volume caused the vibration of the cylinder to be suppressed and the frequency of alternating fluid motion in the wake is reduced. If water velocity is increased and we approach the end of the subcritical regime, introducing gas in volume fraction of 0.025% can result in a premature shift to supercritical flow, which affects vortex induced vibrations and also significantly reduces the drag on the cylinder. 

This research utilized experimental and numerical methods. The research also provided significant learning opportunities and directly benefited two PhD students, three undergraduates, a CalTeach teacher and one teacher in training.

    Vortex induced vibration suppression
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: As fluid moves past a bluff body such as a mooring line, pipe or support column, alternating flow patterns are introduced into the wake and these induce vibration in the structure. In single phase flow (e.g., just water) this vortex induced vibration mechanism is fairly well understood, and based on the wake characteristics can be broadly classified as subcritical flow (generally at lower speeds) or supercritical flow (generally at higher speeds). However, when gas bubbles are introduced into the water flow the wake behavior changes in ways that are less understood. Previous studies have shown that the frequency of vortices shed in the wake can be altered due to the presence of the bubbles in water, and that this change is dependent on the speed of the flow, the geometry of the bluff body (e.g., diameter of the cylinder), bubble size, and gas volume fraction. Our study focused on the influence of these parameters on modification of the flow past the cylinder, and on the cylinders vibration frequency and amplitude. The focus was on better understanding the physical mechanisms that cause these changes. The key findings are detailed in (published and soon to be published) journal papers and shared with the community in presentations where the mechanisms thought to cause the changes are discussed in depth. For brevity we only note the most striking findings in this outcomes report. For gas volume fractions orders of magnitude smaller than expected to significantly influence the flow we found that under some of the experimental conditions the vortex induced vibrations were suppressed and the flow regime could be shifted from subcritical to supercritical. Specifically, in the subcritical regime, we found that introducing mere 0.01% gas by volume caused the vibration of the cylinder to be suppressed and the frequency of alternating fluid motion in the wake is reduced. If water velocity is increased and we approach the end of the subcritical regime, introducing gas in volume fraction of 0.025% can result in a premature shift to supercritical flow, which affects vortex induced vibrations and also significantly reduces the drag on the cylinder. This research utilized experimental and numerical methods. The research also provided significant learning opportunities and directly benefited two PhD students, three undergraduates, a CalTeach teacher and one teacher in training.
